transcripts.text: Should we talk now?  I don't think we actually talked about dating.  Don't date feminists.

Okay.
I hope.
The only reason I want to bring it, I don't want to talk about my book because that's boring.
But your book is offensive.

It is offensive.  The Tactical Guide to Women is the most misogynistic sounding title.  But if you read the introduction, even if you read as much as the subtitle, it starts to come into focus.  This is not a misogynistic book.  But the reason I wrote this book... is because I found in my clinical practice, so many guys ending up in family court or divorced or just miserable at home or alcoholic or addicted to different things or having anxiety disorders, depression.  And so much of it comes back to the choice of the women that they bring into their lives.  And so I wrote a book that apparently...
The Tactical Guide to Women.

Yeah, it's been well-received apparently, where I talk a lot about how to vet women for... Who are you going to allow into your inner circle?  You should be very selective about who you allow into your inner circle, especially someone who's in such an intimate position as a female partner.  What were you going to say?
My first question is, have they written smears about this book because I can just see how easy it would be to write?

Shockingly, no.  I actually was hoping that some radical angry feminist would give me some free publicity, but there's really not much to object to in here.  I'm saying men should be selective and they should look for character.  Well, if you argue against that, you're sort of indicting yourself as someone who's not worthy of being in someone else's life.
But it's man-centric, so I can imagine.
Maybe it's coming.  I just haven't encountered it.

So, well, you explained basically the gist of it, but I don't know.  You want to elaborate, I guess?  Because we can get into the hard don't date feminists, but we can ease into that or we can just jump off the diving board.

Well, I can give you the gist of the book is that there are some basic characteristics that you should look for, including shared values and the ability, you know, things like maturity and the ability to navigate relationships and conflict and so forth.  Guys are not really taught to look for these things.  Women are very good at, well, they're marginally better than us at talking to their daughters about the character of the men that they bring into their life.
Yeah, good point.

And so the book is really to help men make intelligent decisions about who they bring into life.  So getting back to dating feminism.
Well, is the first chapter, one, don't date a feminist?

No, I don't.  I don't talk about the negative side and so much of the things to avoid because that stuff is out there.  You know, the 14 red flags to avoid in women or whatever.  No, that's marginally useful.  But what's more useful is knowing what to look for. Nothing works if you don't have your mission in order your job doesn't work your relationships don't work. Who said that?

Jordan Peterson.  Yeah, right, right, right.  But, yeah, yeah, yeah.  So then what is it specifically about feminists?  And I'll clarify, too, just before.  It's the woke, intersectional, like, you know, more extreme feminists.

Yeah, not the person who calls herself a feminist because she believes in accountability and so forth.  You should date that person provided the values are lined up and she has all the other prerequisites.  But the angry, bitter, sad, victimized feminists, the most obvious problem with dating anybody who has an ideology... that says I'm the victim and I'm being mistreated is that once the honeymoon is over, guess who the oppressor is?  Because this person has to have an oppressor.  And if this person is thinking that men in general are my oppressor and then the honeymoon starts to fade, which is somewhere between 12 and 18 months, our brain chemistry starts to reach its baseline and we start to see the other person as a real person, not as an idealized person.  Then at that point and I've seen this like clockwork when when couples come in and the woman has a Identitarian feminist ideology that that finds its way into the relationship.  and I don't see that a whole lot because And frankly, there's not a lot of hardcore feminists off campus and functioning in the real world because it's such a dysfunctional way of going through the world that people don't have much tolerance for it other than on campus.  You know, you're celebrated on campus, but it always finds its way into the relationship.  And then the man becomes the oppressor.  And you can't argue with somebody constructively if they think that you are mistreating them at every turn.
Right.  Do you think there's an inverse to that?  Is there a version for women you could say?  Is there certain men they shouldn't date?
Yeah, they actually have written...
Same thing, Toxic Feminist Male.

Yeah, I wrote a book called The Practical Guide to Men.  It's gotten a lot less press.  The Tactical Guide to Women has done very well for me, so it's clearly filling some kind of a niche out there.  But yeah, there are men that women probably shouldn't date.  Going through the checklist, he has to be able to navigate difficulties, and he should probably be a little bit stoic so he can handle things, and he should... Have his mission in order, because if he doesn't have his mission in order, then you don't really know who you're dating.  And this is more characteristic of men than women, that men need to have that in place to be able to function well.

That's interesting because I've never heard it from a clinical or an academic standpoint, but I've always described my mission that way.  Like I have a mission.  I have a plan.  I know what I'm doing.  And I'm navigating various paths, but I've always, my entire life, had a quest that I've been on.  And I wonder if that is one of the reasons why millennial men have been – Maybe it's fair to be so hard on them as I am, but so many have kind of been lost or ineffective or reclusive.  It's because they've never found their mission.  In reference to this, we mentioned Jordan Peterson.  One of the things I've said in the past is that I think Jordan Peterson fills the role of a loss of purpose because we've become so comfortable and successful in our lives.  So now you have people who are lost, who have nothing to live for.  And he says, find the heaviest thing you can and carry it.  Yes.  And that's them finding their mission.  Yes.  And then to bring it back to dating, I wonder if one of the reasons, if there's like a causational or correlational effect between a lot of these women who hate men.  and being surrounded by ineffective missionless men.  So then they in turn resent them and think men are bad, right?

How could you not resent somebody if you're in that position and you're with somebody that you know that, well, you don't know that, but I take it as a given that a man has to have his mission in order for his life to function correctly.  And if he's not taking care of himself, which is getting his mission in order, keeping his body in order, having something that he's working toward, how could you not get a little bit resentful towards someone like that?
Well, yeah.  So in turn, women shouldn't date men without a mission?  Or is there a better way?

Well, it's tricky because young guys in their 20s, they're not all like you.  And so maybe part of what you see among millennials is that young guys in general... have to struggle a little bit.  Most of us have to struggle a little bit to find our mission.  So it can look like a guy in his twenties is aimless when really he's working pretty hard to figure out where he's going.  He just doesn't have his direction yet.  And that, that really stinks about being in your twenties for most guys is that you are at a position where now you are expected your man, you're expected to know where you're going, but you don't know where you're going yet.  Yeah.  And it's, it's a tough place to be in.

I mean, I feel like when I was in my 20s, my early 20s, I was, you know, bouncing around.  I was in LA.  I was briefly homeless.  I, you know, moved across the country a couple times, but I still had a mission.  And it's not like I had a roadmap where I'm like, I'm going to be here in five years.  It was kind of like, I must remain focused.
You were going forward.

I guess maybe, yeah.  I was always doing stuff. that feminist men that you're asserting, and I wouldn't disagree, that they have that nice guy cluster of behaviors, that covert sort of aggression and just that bitterness.

Yeah.  yes and that's that's one of the things that you know.  i i have worked with um the kink community because what happened early in my practice is someone came in and they were part of the king community and i got really curious like how does this work?  because i feel like i didn't know how how to really work with the specifics of their situation.  so i said show me around take me.  so i went to some dungeons i went to some clubs and i started talking to people and figuring out how this works and some part of it.  i can wrap my head around.  polyamory is one that i i really have trouble wrapping my head around from a male perspective because exactly i cannot even fathom sharing my wife with anybody.  i'm toxic i guess you know i'm very possessive like the thought of that it just.  it kind of makes me a little crazy.  so it's up to your point.
well yeah but this is something you typically will see more among the feminists and the left.  so i have to.  i can only imagine why would a woman need to go to another man to be satisfied?

That guy's repulsive.

I don't know what you'd call it.  Which makes the snow go nuts.  So when the avalanche starts, he ditches his family and runs and hides. So I guess I bring this up because it's like, now in a mainstream movie, the plot point is that men should be traditional, but that's toxic.  And the wife is actually mad.  So I guess, I don't know.  I think it's interesting that we have this sort of duality or maybe duality is not the right word, but paradox in mainstream pop culture where you have all of these things saying men should behave a certain way, but then you simultaneously have other movies screaming not to behave a certain way.  Right.  How can anyone figure out what they're supposed to do?  Yeah.

I think the answer is you ignore it all and you do what you want.  That's what I do.  I want to be careful how I say this.  Not necessarily what you want to do because what you want to do is not necessarily something that's going to bring you meaning.  But one of the things that every young guy has to figure out is how is he going to put a dent in the universe, as one of my friends says.  How is he going to do something that he can look back on?  That's the much more important question.  You can do something that's difficult and valuable, not necessarily fun.  Maybe it's fun too.
But I think a lot of guys want legacy.  And so that's why a lot of these guys who go down the path that is incorrect become extremely dangerous and violent.  Their path to legacy is evil.
Yeah.  But they want something.  And they're a very small group.
Right, right.  Of course.
